A popular vote would compel candidates to engage with all constituents, ensuring that every voice is heard, regardless of geography.

Instead of term limits, we should focus on enhancing transparency and accountability measures to combat corruption and complacency.

Term limits for elected officials can undermine the benefits of experience and institutional knowledge, which are critical for effective governance. By imposing limits, we risk losing seasoned leaders who understand the complexities of their roles and the needs of their constituents. Additionally, it may encourage a constant influx of inexperienced individuals who may not be equipped to make informed decisions.

Term limits for all elected officials prevent the entrenchment of power, promote fresh ideas, and encourage greater civic engagement. Limiting terms ensures that new leaders have the opportunity to represent diverse perspectives, reducing the risk of corruption and complacency inherent in prolonged tenures.

Term limits can lead to a lack of continuity and stability in government, disrupting long-term plans and initiatives that require sustained leadership. They may also incentivize politicians to prioritize short-term gains over long-term solutions, knowing they will soon leave office. Furthermore, voters should have the power to decide who represents them, rather than having limits imposed that could dismiss capable leaders.
